DOC.HEAD: Searchers Still Have No Sign Of Missing Airplane
Eds: INSERTS new 3rd graf, `Darkness forced ...' to UPDATE with search called off for night. Phegn in penultimate graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Blustery winds and fresh snow frustrated rescue workers searching for a twin-engine airplane that disappeared during a snowstorm with six people aboard, authorities said Sunday. About 20 airplanes and helicopters were searching a four-county area of the Catskill Mountains for the Piper Navajo that apparently crashed Friday night, state police Sgt. John Vansteenburg said in Catskill. Darkness forced rescuers to call off the search until Monday morning, trooper Robert Carl said. ``We've found no sign,'' said Lt. George Ezzo, who is heading a team of forest rangers in the search. Rescuers gave up searching on foot because the plane ``could be anywhere along a 100-mile line,'' he said. The airplane took off Friday afternoon from Warren County Airport, 50 miles north of Albany, bound for Orange County Airport just north of New York City, said Civil Air Patrol spokeswoman Ann MacMillan. It was reported about 30 miles south of Albany when it disappeared, she said. The plane took off in blustery weather, and as much as 7 inches of snow fell in the area. Although skies were clear Sunday, snow that has fallen since Friday may have buried the plane, Vansteenburg said. Salvatore Arlotta, a vice president of the Middletown-based environmental consulting firm Wehran Engineering, and Peter Lovi, a scientist for the company, were returning from a trip to a landfill project northeast of Glens Falls, said Wehran spokeswoman Phyllis Phegn. Authorities have not released the names of the pilot or the other three passengers.
